citing_paper_authors: György, Szarvas | Veronika, Vincze | Richárd, Farkas | János, Csirik
raw_text: Medlock and Briscoe (2007) proposed a weakly supervised setting for hedge classification in scientific texts where the aim is to minimise human supervision needed to obtain an adequate amount of training data
clean_text: Medlock and Briscoe (2007) proposed a weakly supervised setting for hedge classification in scientific texts where the aim is to minimise human supervision needed to obtain an adequate amount of training data.

citing_paper_authors: György, Szarvas | Veronika, Vincze | Richárd, Farkas | János, Csirik
raw_text: The authors are only aware of the following related corpora:? The Hedge classification corpus (Medlock and Briscoe, 2007), which has been annotated for hedge cues (at the sentence level) and consists of five full biological research papers (1537 sentences)
clean_text: The authors are only aware of the following related corpora: the Hedge classification corpus (Medlock and Briscoe, 2007), which has been annotated for hedge cues (at the sentence level) and consists of five full biological research papers (1537 sentences).

citing_paper_authors: György, Szarvas | Veronika, Vincze | Richárd, Farkas | János, Csirik
raw_text: 5 articles from FlyBase (the same data were used by Medlock and Briscoe (2007) for evaluating sentence-level hedge classifiers) and 4 articles from the open access BMC Bioinformatics website were downloaded and annotated for negations, uncertainty and their scopes
clean_text: 5 articles from FlyBase (the same data were used by Medlock and Briscoe (2007) for evaluating sentence-level hedge classifiers) and 4 articles from the open access BMC Bioinformatics website were downloaded and annotated for negations, uncertainty and their scopes.

raw_text: Solving the sentence level task, Medlock and Briscoe (2007) used single words as input features in order to classify sentences from biological articles as speculative or non speculative
clean_text: Solving the sentence level task, Medlock and Briscoe (2007) used single words as input features in order to classify sentences from biological articles as speculative or non speculative.

raw_text: A misinterpretation of the BioScope paper (Szarvas et al, 2008) led us to believe that five of the nine full articles in the training data were annotated using the guidelines of Medlock and Briscoe (2007)
clean_text: A misinterpretation of the BioScope paper (Szarvas et al, 2008) led us to believe that five of the nine full articles in the training data were annotated using the guidelines of Medlock and Briscoe (2007).

raw_text: Medlock and Briscoe (2007) extended the work of Light et al (2004) by refining their annotation guidelines and creating a publicly available data set (FlyBase data set) for speculative sentence classification
clean_text: Medlock and Briscoe (2007) extended the work of Light et al (2004) by refining their annotation guidelines and creating a publicly available data set (FlyBase data set) for speculative sentence classification.

raw_text: Szarvas (2008) extended the weakly supervised machine learning methodology of MedlockandBriscoe (2007) by applying feature selection to reduce the number of candidate keywords, by using limited manual supervision to filter the features, and by extending the feature representation with bi grams and trigrams
clean_text: Szarvas (2008) extended the weakly supervised machine learning methodology of Medlock and Briscoe (2007) by applying feature selection to reduce the number of candidate keywords, by using limited manual supervision to filter the features, and by extending the feature representation with bigrams and trigrams.

raw_text: In addition, by fol lowing the annotation guidelines of Medlock and Briscoe (2007), Szarvas (2008) made available the BMC Bioinformatics data set, by annotating four full text papers from the open access BMC Bioinformatics website
clean_text: In addition, by following the annotation guidelines of Medlock and Briscoe (2007), Szarvas (2008) made available the BMC Bioinformatics data set, by annotating four full text papers from the open access BMC Bioinformatics website.

citing_paper_authors: Yi, Zheng | Qifeng, Dai | Qiming, Luo | Enhong, Chen
raw_text: In related work, Szarvas (2008) extended the methodology of Medlock and Briscoe (2007), and presented a hedge detection method in biomedical texts with a weakly supervised selection of keywords
clean_text: In related work, Szarvas (2008) extended the methodology of Medlock and Briscoe (2007), and presented a hedge detection method in biomedical texts with a weakly supervised selection of keywords.

citing_paper_authors: Feng, Ji | Xipeng, Qiu | Xuanjing, Huang
raw_text: For speculative sentences detection, Medlock and Briscoe (2007) report their approach based on weakly supervised learning
clean_text: For speculative sentences detection, Medlock and Briscoe (2007) report their approach based on weakly supervised learning.

raw_text: Medlock and Briscoe (2007) also used single words as input features in order to classify sentences from scientific articles in biomedical domain as speculative or non-speculative
clean_text: Medlock and Briscoe (2007) also used single words as input features in order to classify sentences from scientific articles in biomedical domain as speculative or non-speculative.

raw_text: Medlock and Briscoe (2007) use a similar baseline as the one adopted by Light et al (2004) ,i.e. a na ?ve algorithm based on substring matching, but with a different list of terms to match against
clean_text: Medlock and Briscoe (2007) use a similar baseline as the one adopted by Light et al (2004), i.e. a naive algorithm based on substring matching, but with a different list of terms to match against.

raw_text: However Medlock and Briscoe (2007) note that their model is unsuccessful in identifying assertive statements of knowledge paucity which are generally marked rather syntactically than lexically
clean_text: However Medlock and Briscoe (2007) note that their model is unsuccessful in identifying assertive statements of knowledge paucity which are generally marked rather syntactically than lexically.

raw_text: Kilicoglu and Bergler (2008) did experiments on the same dataset as Medlock and Briscoe (2007) and their experimental results proved that the classification accuracy can be improved by approximately 9% (from an F-score of 76% to an F-score of 85%) if syntactic and semantic information are incorporated
clean_text: Kilicoglu and Bergler (2008) did experiments on the same dataset as Medlock and Briscoe (2007) and their experimental results proved that the classification accuracy can be improved by approximately 9% (from an F-score of 76% to an F-score of 85%) if syntactic and semantic information are incorporated.

raw_text: The experiments run by Medlock (2008) on the same dataset as Medlock and Briscoe (2007) show that adding features based on part-of speech tags to a bag-of-words input representation can slightly improve the accuracy, but the? improvements are marginal and not statistically significant?
clean_text: The experiments run by Medlock (2008) on the same dataset as Medlock and Briscoe (2007) show that adding features based on part-of speech tags to a bag-of-words input representation can slightly improve the accuracy, but the improvements are marginal and not statistically significant.

raw_text: Other early work focused on semi supervised learning due to a lack of annotated datasets (Medlock and Briscoe, 2007)
clean_text: Other early work focused on semi supervised learning due to a lack of annotated datasets (Medlock and Briscoe, 2007).

raw_text: We can then use the large amounts of unannotated sentences that are available to extract n-gram features that have high uncertainty class conditional probability and add them to our training set with those features labeled as hedges as described in Medlock and Briscoe (2007)
clean_text: We can then use the large amounts of unannotated sentences that are available to extract n-gram features that have high uncertainty class conditional probability and add them to our training set with those features labeled as hedges as described in Medlock and Briscoe (2007).

citing_paper_authors: Richárd, Farkas | Veronika, Vincze | György, Móra | János, Csirik | György, Szarvas
raw_text: Medlock and Briscoe (2007) used single words as input feature sin order to classify sentences from biological articles (FlyBase) as speculative or non-speculative based on semi-automatically collected training examples
clean_text: Medlock and Briscoe (2007) used single words as input feature sin order to classify sentences from biological articles (FlyBase) as speculative or non-speculative based on semi-automatically collected training examples.

citing_paper_authors: Richárd, Farkas | Veronika, Vincze | György, Móra | János, Csirik | György, Szarvas
raw_text: Szarvas (2008) extended the methodology of Medlock and Briscoe (2007) to use n-gram features and a semi-supervised selection of the keyword features
clean_text: Szarvas (2008) extended the methodology of Medlock and Briscoe (2007) to use n-gram features and a semi-supervised selection of the keyword features.

citing_paper_authors: Guillermo, Moncecchi | Jean-Luc, Minel | Dina, Wonsever
raw_text: Early work on speculative language detection tried to classify a sentence either as speculative or non-speculative (see, for example, Medlock and Briscoe (2007))
clean_text: Early work on speculative language detection tried to classify a sentence either as speculative or non-speculative (see, for example, Medlock and Briscoe (2007)).
